diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: Kawasaki disease is a rare condition that mainly affects children under the age of 5. It's characterized by inflammation of blood vessels throughout the body and can lead to coronary artery aneurysms. Common symptoms include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, redness in the eyes (conjunctivitis), swollen lymph nodes, and mucous membrane changes in the mouth and throat.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: Scarlet fever is an infectious disease resulting from a group A streptococcus (group A strep) infection, known for its distinct rash. Symptoms typically include sore throat, fever, and a sandpaper-like rash, which may be accompanied by other signs like conjunctivitis and desquamation.

diagnoses.name: Viral Exanthem
diagnoses.description: Viral exanthem is a rash caused by a viral infection. Common causes include measles, rubella, and erythema infectiosum. Symptoms can vary widely but often include fever, maculopapular rash, and general malaise.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
diagnoses.description: DRESS syndrome is a serious condition caused by a reaction to medication. Symptoms may include a rash, fever, lymphadenopathy, and involvement of internal organs such as the liver, kidney, or lungs. Thrombocytosis and pyuria might also be observed due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome is a rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Symptoms include flu-like symptoms, a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters, eventually causing the skin to die and shed.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Toxic Shock Syndrome is a rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections. It has been associated with tampon use, but can also occur in other situations, such as after surgery. Symptoms include sudden fever, rash, low blood pressure, and peeling skin.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory disease that can occur as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever. Symptoms may include fever, painful and tender joints, rash, and involuntary muscle movements.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: Rubella, also known as German measles, is a contagious viral infection best known by its distinctive red rash. While it's generally mild in children, rubella can cause serious complications during pregnancy.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: Measles is a highly contagious viral infection that causes a total-body skin rash and flu-like symptoms, including fever, cough, and conjunctivitis. It has a well-established relationship with maculopapular rash.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever is a bacterial disease spread by ticks. It is characterized by a sudden onset of fever and headache, followed by a rash that starts on the wrists and ankles and may then spread to the trunk.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, hepatitis C, Epstein-Barr virus)
Schizophrenia (considering the presence of psychosis with no direct link to other symptoms)
Tuberculosis (considering the pleural effusion and potential systemic involvement)
Lymphoma (specifically considering leukopenia and possible systemic symptoms)
Sjögren's Syndrome with neurological and hematological manifestations
Vasculitis, specifically CNS vasculitis or ANCA-associated vasculitis
Sarcoidosis with Löfgren's syndrome (arthropathy, erythema nodosum) and neurosarcoidosis
Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS) with inflammatory arthritis
Viral infection (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Primary angiitis of the central nervous system
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.details: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. Symptoms often include irregular menstrual cycles, infertility, and can impact blood pressure and blood sugar levels.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.details: A rare tumor of the adrenal gland tissue causing an overproduction of adrenal hormones like adrenaline, leading to hypertension, tachycardia, and potentially affecting glucose metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.details: Overactivity of the thyroid gland leading to excessive production of thyroid hormones, which can cause elevated heart rate, weight loss, and irregular menstrual cycles.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.details: A metabolic disease that causes high blood sugar. Long-term complications of diabetes can include infertility and hypoglycemia, especially in cases where blood sugar is not well-managed.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system attacks its tissues, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs, which can explain hypoglycemia, lymphadenopathy, and potentially orthostatic issues.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A condition caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. It can lead to hypertension, glucose intolerance, and symptoms affecting the reproductive system.

diagnoses.name: Primary Aldosteronism
diagnoses.details: Also known as Conn's syndrome, it’s a condition of excess production of the hormone aldosterone by the adrenal glands, which leads to hypertension and can affect blood glucose levels.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.details: Persistent kidney damage that can lead to hypertension and affect the body's ability to filter waste, sometimes leading to disturbances in menstrual cycles and causing symptoms similar to hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.details: An adrenal insufficiency where the body produces insufficient amounts of certain hormones, including cortisol and aldosterone, which can manifest as hypotension, but with proper management might cause a compensatory hypertension response.

diagnoses.name: Hypopituitarism
diagnoses.details: A condition in which the pituitary gland doesn't produce normal amounts of some or all of its hormones, which can lead to infertility, hypoglycemia, and potentially influence blood pressure.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (e.g., Epstein-Barr virus, leading to infectious mononucleosis)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to hypotension, angioedema, abdominal cramps, and ultimately, syncope.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the adrenal glands causing insufficient production of cortisol and aldosterone, leading to hypotension, abdominal cramps, and in some cases, syncope.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting (syncope) that can be associated with various triggers, including stress, pain, or standing for long periods. May lead to hypotension and in rare cases, incontinence due to loss of muscle control during the episode.

diagnoses.name: Hypovolemic Shock
diagnoses.description: A condition of severe blood and fluid loss making the heart unable to pump enough blood to the body, which can cause hypotension, syncope, and in severe cases, incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Acute Intestinal Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare complication of angioedema involving the intestines, leading to abdominal cramps, hypotension, and possibly syncope due to the reduction of blood flow.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing recurring episodes of severe swelling (angioedema), which can affect various parts of the body, including the abdomen, causing abdominal cramps and potentially hypotension and syncope.

diagnoses.name: Neurocardiogenic Syncope
diagnoses.description: A form of dysautonomia that is characterized by an inappropriate drop in blood pressure while standing, leading to syncope. It can be associated with incontinence during the episode.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections. Symptoms include sudden high fever, hypotension, syncope, and possibly a rash resembling a sunburn.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of the adrenal gland tissue. It results in the production of excess hormones leading to episodes of hypertension, but it can paradoxically cause hypotension, abdominal cramps, and syncope.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection, which can lead to tissue damage, organ failure, and death. Symptoms can include hypotension, abdominal cramps, and in severe cases, syncope.

diagnoses: Toxic ingestion (e.g., chemical or biological toxins)

diagnoses.name: Septic Shock
diagnoses.description: A severe infection leading to overwhelming systemic inflammation, resulting in hypotension, hypoxia, and potentially multi-organ failure.

diagnoses.name: Neurocardiogenic Syncope
diagnoses.description: A reflex syncope caused by a sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure, leading to fainting, often in response to a trigger such as prolonged standing, emotional stress, or seeing blood.

diagnoses.name: Acute Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: A rapid onset or worsening of symptoms such as shortness of breath (hypoxia), fatigue, or fluid retention due to the heart's inability to pump blood effectively. Hypotension and syncope may also occur.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause hypotension, hypoxia, and in rare cases, incontinence due to severe systemic reaction.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition where the adrenal glands produce insufficient amounts of certain hormones, which can lead to hypotension, fatigue, and if severe, can contribute to incontinence and hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Pulmonary Embolism
diagnoses.description: A blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in your lungs. In most cases, pulmonary embolism is caused by blood clots that travel to your lungs from your legs or other parts of your body (deep vein thrombosis). It can lead to hypoxia, syncope, and hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Myocardial Infarction
diagnoses.description: A blockage of blood flow to the heart muscle that can cause chest pain, hypotension, hypoxia, and in some cases, syncope due to a decrease in cardiac output.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: An interruption or reduction in the supply of blood to the brain. This can lead to symptoms like incontinence and syncope due to the sudden decrease in cerebral blood flow.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting. It occurs when the part of your nervous system that regulates heart rate and blood pressure malfunctions in response to a trigger, such as emotional distress or the sight of blood, leading to syncope, and can also indirectly cause hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection
diagnoses.description: While not directly linked to hypoxia, hypotension, or syncope, a severe urinary tract infection could potentially result in systemic infection (sepsis), which could then lead to these symptoms along with incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerve fibers, leading to delayed response or permanent nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells start to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that might occur with symptoms before the actual headache begins. Symptoms include visual disturbances or other sensory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A group of neurological diseases that mainly involve the nerve cells (neurons) responsible for controlling voluntary muscle movement. The disease is progressive, resulting in difficulty speaking, swallowing, and eventually breathing.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can be cancerous (malignant) or non-cancerous (benign). It can cause symptoms depending on the part of the brain it is affecting.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor that develops on the balance and hearing nerves leading from your inner ear to your brain. The pressure from the tumor on the nerves can lead to hearing loss and balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. It affects the feet and legs first, followed by the hands and arms. Symptoms include tingling, numbness, pain, or a burning feeling in the affected areas.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy
diagnoses.description: A rare neurological disorder that impairs your body's involuntary functions, including blood pressure, heart rate, bladder function, and digestion.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs.

A stroke happens when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or severely reduced, depriving brain tissue of oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include dysphagia, paresthesia, headache, aphasia, and scotoma depending on the area of the brain affected.

Multiple Sclerosis is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). Early signs and symptoms may include fatigue, difficulty walking, paresthesias, such as numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, and dysphagia.

Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that includes visual disturbances such as scotomas, and other neurological impairments such as aphasia, paresthesia, and sometimes motor weakness. Headaches are a primary symptom.

Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms include dysphagia, paresthesia, headache, and sometimes aphasia or scotoma.

A brain tumor can cause varying neurological symptoms based on the tumor’s location. These can include headaches, seizures, paresthesias, difficulties with speech such as aphasia, and vision problems like scotomas.

Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, it affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord. Early symptoms can include muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), and speech problems, but it would less commonly cause headaches, paresthesia, aphasia, or scotoma directly.

Guillain-Barré Syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Initial symptoms can include weakness and tingling in your extremities. It can progress rapidly, potentially leading to problems with swallowing (dysphagia) and other neurological deficits.

This is a chronic autoimmune, neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs. It can cause dysphagia and sometimes affects the neuromuscular junctions related to eye movements, potentially causing vision issues.

A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, typically from an infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, weakness, confusion, seizures, and problems with speech and vision, depending on the abscess location.

A tick-borne illness that can affect the nervous system, causing a range of neurological symptoms weeks to months after the tick bite. This can include facial palsy, which might affect swallowing, neuropathies including paresthesia, and rarely encephalitis which could explain headaches, aphasia, and vision disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves neurological phenomena (aura) like visual disturbances (scotomas, or blind spots) and sensory symptoms. Headache, numbness, or weakness can follow the aura.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. It can cause symptoms like numbness or weakness on one side of the body, trouble speaking, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is characterized by temporary stroke-like symptoms such as paralysis, numbness, and speech difficulties, including scotomas and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause seizures, headaches, weakness, numbness, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Neuromyelitis Optica (Devic's Disease)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder affecting the eyes and spinal cord. Symptoms may include visual impairments such as scotoma, weakness, numbness, and in severe cases, paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. Symptoms include numbness, weakness, and pain, particularly in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing the whole body.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include headache, fatigue, fever, and skin rash called erythema migrans. If untreated, it can lead to neurological problems like facial palsy, numbness, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause headache, numbness, weakness, and many other symptoms. Specific symptoms depend on which blood vessels, organs, or other body systems are affected.

diagnoses: Infections (Viral, Bacterial, or Fungal leading to secondary vasculitis or immune response)
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Hepatitis B or C with extrahepatic manifestations

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms, including pericarditis, arthralgias or arthritis (arthropathy), and neuropsychiatric lupus (which may present as psychosis). Kidney involvement can cause proteinuria, and dermatologic manifestations may include telangiectasias, although they are more commonly associated with other conditions.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD combines features of various systemic autoimmune diseases like SLE and systemic sclerosis, and may present with arthralgia, myositis, pericarditis, and lung abnormalities. Telangiectasias and proteinuria can also be observed due to its overlap with systemic sclerosis and SLE, respectively.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can lead to skin changes including telangiectasias, renal involvement manifesting as proteinuria, and can involve the heart (pericarditis). Articular involvement can result in arthropathy, and there is a recognized overlap between scleroderma and psychiatric manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with Extra-articular Manifestations
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for its impact on joints (arthropathy), RA can have extra-articular manifestations including pericarditis and rarely renal involvement (proteinuria). Neuropsychiatric symptoms (including psychosis) though uncommon, can be part of RA or its treatments. Telangiectasias are less commonly associated but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.rationale: APS can cause a wide range of symptoms due to its hypercoagulable state, including renal involvement (proteinuria) and potentially affecting the brain (psychosis). Though not typical, pericarditis and joint symptoms can occur. Telangiectasias are not hallmark features but may appear in overlap syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Dermatomyositis features muscle weakness and distinctive skin changes, which can include telangiectasias. While primarily affecting skin and muscles, it can also involve the lungs, heart (pericarditis), and joints (arthropathy). Renal involvement including proteinuria is rare but possible.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
diagnoses.rationale: Vasculitides can affect multiple organ systems, including the kidneys (proteinuria), heart (pericarditis), and musculoskeletal system (arthropathy). Neurological involvement can lead to psychiatric symptoms. Telangiectasias are not a primary feature but may occur depending on the specific type of vasculitis.

diagnoses.name: Undifferentiated Connective Tissue Disease (UCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: UCTD represents conditions that have features of connective tissue diseases but do not fulfill the criteria for a specific disease. Symptoms can include arthropathy, pericarditis, and kidney involvement (proteinuria). Telangiectasias and neuropsychiatric symptoms such as psychosis can also be present.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA)
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for its skin and joint involvement, PsA can, in rare cases, involve the kidneys (leading to proteinuria) and heart (pericarditis). Psychiatric symptoms including psychosis can occur, albeit rarely. Telangiectasias are not typically associated with PsA.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: While technically part of the spectrum of SLE manifestations, lupus nephritis specifically refers to the renal involvement leading to proteinuria. Patients may also experience other SLE symptoms including pericarditis, arthropathy, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and skin changes such as telangiectasias.

diagnoses: Raynaud's Phenomenon secondary to another connective tissue disease
